citeinfo.origin: David Karplus - Yellowstone National Park Trail Crew Leader 1997
Spatial Analysis Center - Yellowstone National Park
citeinfo.title: Trail Survey of Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, Montana, Idaho

pubinfo.publish: Yellowstone Center for Resources, Yellowstone National Park

descript.abstract: The main Trail Survey took place during the years of 1997-2000. Differentially corrected GPS (Global Positioning System) data were collected primarily on foot for all existing maintained trails and spur trails to backcountry campsites, attractions and buildings within the boundaries of Yellowstone National Park (YNP).The trails that could not be obtained through the GPS or have been rerouted since the survey were acquired through the uses of 1 meter Digital Orthophoto Quarter Quads (DOQQs) and the help of backcountry rangers with knowledge of where the trails are located. There are also associated GPS data for trail bridges, backcountry campsites, patrol cabins and trail surface type. Trail usage data also documented by using visitor ski and bike trail maps. There are several trails that are missing from this layer, as this is still a work in progress.

descript.purpose: This survey is intended to provide an accurate geographical coverage of trails within Yellowstone National Park for the purposes of maintenance and increased recreational enjoyment.

attracc.attraccr: Data attributes were recorded on-site, during the GPS survey. Backcountry rangers from each ranger district also checked the attribute and location accuracy.

dataqual.logic: All arcs have complete topology. All overshoots or undershoots have been corrected and all unnecessary dangles corrected. The BUILD function in Arc/Info was evoked on 20000809.
dataqual.complete: There are several trail segments within the Yellowstone National Park trail system which have not been surveyed as of August 2000. The areas that have not been checked by a backcountry ranger are the Gallatin and Tower subdistrict. The trails that are still missing from the coverage are Lost Creek Falls, Slough Creek Fishing Access, Fern Cascade, Howard Eaton trail (in old Faithful), Kepler Cascade, segment of South Boundary from Harebell Cabin, segment of Howard Eaton from Artist Point to Sour Creek, Spring Creek Ski Trail and segment of Yellowstone River. As of 20050804 Bike and Ski trails that need to be GPSed: Mammoth Area-Ski: Sheepeater Trail; Bighorn Loop; Indian Creek Loop. Bike: Abandon railroad bed paralleling the Yellowstone River between Gardiner and the park boundary at Reese Creek (5mi). Cayon Area- Ski: ~1.5 mi in on the Cascade Lake Trail; Roller Coaster Trail; Portion of Canyon Rim Trail that dosent't follow road. Tower/Lamar Area-Ski: Lost Lake Trail all the way up to Blacktail Plateau Trail; Cutoff to parking area on Blacktail Plateau Trail. Bike: Rose Creek Service Road behing Yellowstone Institute (crosses creek follows stream up to spring).

horizpa.horizpar: The data produced from GPS field data are assumed to be spatially accurate to within 2-5 meters. Maximum PDOP was set to 6 and data were only collected when at least 4 satellites were readable. Data acquired from DOQQs can have a spatial accuracy within 5-10 meters.

citeinfo.title: Trail Names of Yellowstone National Park

procstep.procdesc: GPS data were collected with Trimble ProXR, PROXL & ProXRS by volunteers on foot during the summer field seasons of 1997, 1998, and 1999.

GPS files were differentially corrected using base station data from the Idaho Fall, Idaho GPS Community Base Station at INEL.The GPS processing software was Trimble Pathfinder Office Versions 2.11 through 2.5.

Data were brought into Arc/Info v7.1. & 8.01 The node errors were eliminated from the coverage by snapping all intersecting arcs together. Arcs representing trails were also snapped to their corresponding bridges and campsites.

Features were quality controlled by verifying the locations of the features with the NPS district rangers. Backcountry trails locations that were not surveyed with a GPS or rerouted with in the three year survey period were obtained by having backcountry rangers from each district identify where the trail is located on a 1-meter DOQQ. Using ArcView, a line was digitized to the specified location. The ArcView shapefile of trails was converted to an Arc/Info coverage using the SHAPEARC command with PRECISION set to DOUBLE HIGH. The coverage was then added to the coverage containing the GPS trails using the PUT command in ArcEdit.
Several trails were removed, moved, added according to instructions from the Backcountry Office. All new data were heads-up digitized on DOQQs.

procstep.procdesc: 2005 trails survey conducted by adding new attribute field, called USAGE. Various maps of area ski trails and bike trails were obtained from the visitor center. These maps were used to populate trail USAGE attribute.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Defines visitor/park usage of trail or road. Hiking; Stock; Biking; Ski; Service Road

overview.eaover: This coverage contains the following attribute fields: SURVEYOR: name of the surveyor; SURVYDAT:date the feature was surveyed; NAME: common trail name. The NAME of the Trail were obtained using Trails Illustrated Map and the Trail Names database created by the Ranger Divsion. TYPE; if the trail is a Main Trail, a Spur trail, an off shoot of the main trail that either goes to a backcountry campsite, attraction or building, a Boardwalk or Paved Path; SURVEY; The survey method is either GPS - using a Globe Positioning System, or Office - using DOQQs in the office and the knowledge of a backcountry ranger familiar with the area.

distinfo.distliab: The National Park Service shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data and related graphics ("GIF" format files) are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such. The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. The related graphics are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not appropriate to use the related graphics as data. The National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an NPS server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the National Park Service, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.
